website_summaries.verdict: Utilizes the Singapore method, which places a focus on concept mastery over memorization.
pros: Clearly defined learning objectives in each section
Offers multiple solution methods to help students arrive at answers
Step-by-step format is a systematic approach that won't overwhelm
cons: Word problems are terse, and there is only one problem per page

customer_reviews.title: Excellent
customer_reviews.text: I bought these for my kids. At the time, I wanted to enable them to engage with math beyond what they were doing at school. Unfortunately, most of the materials that I looked at were geared towards rote repetition. The Singapore Math books, by contrast, are excellent. They focus on creative problem solving and force children to really think through the materials. If you are wondering why Singapore's students are doing fabulously on the PISA tests that test student achievement across nations, here is the answer. Strongly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: Chris Austin

customer_reviews.text: I have heard good things about this course so I bought it for my 13 year old whom is home schooled. If you are not familiar with the course already, I would not recommend the workbook. There is literally one word problem per PAGE; which contains about 3 sentences! The rest of the blank space is to show your work. We have used the solution page to work through some of the equations. Even doing that it is hard to determine why steps were takien to get the solution. There is no word explanation, simply the answers to various steps to get the final answer.

customer_reviews.title: Not story problems! No!
customer_reviews.text: The dreaded story problems have been around forever and let students deal with some real world uses of what they’ve been studying. Other than the math itself, they require reading, organization, logic and combining all of that to reach a solution. Unfortunately, the problems are less story and more a short digest of story types of problems. If followed, there should be some light bulb moments while working through this book. The answer section is very valuable and should be referred to by the instructor to make sure shortcuts aren’t taken due to experience. They use diagrams which is great. Drawing a “picture” really helps in understanding concepts and methods.
customer_reviews.author: Tanstaafl

customer_reviews.title: Daily practice or review? Your choice!
customer_reviews.text: Singapore math review books really work with our homeschool curriculum, as they function as review for Saxon Math, as the 2 are very close. Word problems are most kids downfall, but this book can go a long way in not only getting them more comfortable with them, but with enough space, they can work out their answers on the same page, and take 1 problem per day. i would say this grade level is really advanced 5th to 7th, and the problems do get progressively harder, helping to build confidence as well! Great for use during the school year, or keeping skills sharp over the Summer

customer_reviews.title: Helpful for students who are using the system but also a good way to expand the mathematical understanding of students of ...
customer_reviews.text: Word problems are an important component of the Singapore system. This method embraces an approach that eschews the typical Western styled drills and memorization for a concept driven approach. This book is simple to follow and enhances logic skills. Helpful for students who are using the system but also a good way to expand the mathematical understanding of students of the traditional method.

customer_reviews.title: Logic Over Rote Teaching & Learning

The Singapore Series reinforces analytical and critical thinking skills and makes word problems easier to work through as many find word problems overwhelming. Users apply logic and do not learn by rote.

customer_reviews.title: First thoughts
customer_reviews.text: I bought this because I've read a lot in the press about Singapore's success on international tests. It looks like it lives up to its expectations. It demonstrates solutions to word problems using simple drawings of rods to show the relationships of the various quatities (the way Euclid would have done it). The problems also require several steps to solve while most American textbooks need only one or two. I plan on fully integrating this system into my 7th grade pre-algebra class by starting with the 4th grade book. I think this type of relational reasoning and number sense is what they have been missing.
customer_reviews.author: Tom Foster
